titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Annette Braun (1884-1978) was a botanist, artist, photographer, writer, homemaker, and noted microlepidopterist. She received her bachelor's, master's, and Ph.D. degrees in zoology from the University of Cincinnati. She was the first woman to receive a Ph.D. from the University. Her 1911 doctoral thesis was "Observations in the Development of Color in the Pupal Wings of Several Species of Lithocolletis." She taught briefly at the University, the only paid job she ever held. She lived with and assisted her sister Lucy (a botanist and professor at the University of Cincinnati) in writing scientific papers and books. She collected and studied Microlepidoptera, and published four monographs and 63 articles. She was elected a Correspondent to the Academy of Natural Sciences in 1949, where she had been an Honorary Life Member since 1930.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a typed manuscript of Braun's paper, "Origin of the Heteroneurous Type of Lepidopterous Venation," and two charts displaying wings with species name, degree of enlargement, and code numbers. The charts were probably drawn by Braun.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
